steps.title: Set your stitch length to "satin" or nearly zero in length.
steps.content: Set your stitch length to "satin" or nearly zero in length. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Put your buttonhole foot on the machine if you have one.
steps.content: Put your buttonhole foot on the machine if you have one. While you can make a buttonhole with the "regular" presser foot attachment, the buttonhole foot helps you measure and make buttonholes of equal length easily. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Measure the placement of your needed buttonhole(s).
steps.content: Measure the placement of your needed buttonhole(s). [3] X Research source

steps.title: Mark the placement with pins or tailor's chalk.
steps.content: Mark the placement with pins or tailor's chalk. [4] X Research source [5] X Research source

steps.title: Place your presser foot at one end of the buttonhole marking.
steps.content: Place your presser foot at one end of the buttonhole marking. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Zig Zag or Satin Stitch a bar
steps.content: Zig Zag or Satin Stitch a bar the entire width of the buttonhole. (See No. 1 in drawing)

steps.title: Set the stitch width to half the width and stitch down on side of the button hole to the other end.
steps.content: Set the stitch width to half the width and stitch down on side of the button hole to the other end. [7] X Research source (See No. 2 in drawing)

steps.title: Zig Zag or Satin Stitch a bar the entire width of the button hole at the far end.
steps.content: Zig Zag or Satin Stitch a bar the entire width of the button hole at the far end. (See No. 3 in drawing)

steps.title: Re-set your stitch width to half the width and return back to your starting point, keeping your second stitch line parallel to the first.
steps.content: Re-set your stitch width to half the width and return back to your starting point, keeping your second stitch line parallel to the first. (See No. 4 in drawing)

steps.title: Repeat the process for a thicker and more solid stitching line (and therefore buttonhole edge).
steps.content: Repeat the process for a thicker and more solid stitching line (and therefore buttonhole edge). [8] X Research source

steps.title: Use a seam ripper
steps.content: Use a seam ripper or sharp scissor to open the area between the sewn edges. Take care not to cut into the threads.

steps.title: Measure and mark your buttonhole carefully.
steps.content: Measure and mark your buttonhole carefully.

steps.title: Snip or cut the opening,
steps.content: Snip or cut the opening, taking care to leave few, if any, loose threads.

steps.title: Thread a needle and tie a knot.
steps.content: Thread a needle and tie a knot.

steps.title: Bring the needle up from the back
steps.content: Bring the needle up from the back side of the material.

steps.title: Loop the thread through the buttonhole and back up through the material.
steps.content: Loop the thread through the buttonhole and back up through the material.

steps.title: Pass the needle through the loop formed
steps.content: Pass the needle through the loop formed and pull snug.

steps.title: Continue around the perimeter of the buttonhole slit until all raw edges are covered firmly and smoothly.
steps.content: Continue around the perimeter of the buttonhole slit until all raw edges are covered firmly and smoothly. You can roll the raw edge slightly as you stitch if you wish.
